;黑海出口走廊崩溃，允许出口超过 32过去一年中乌克兰粮食产量减少了 100 万吨，应该不会产生什么直接影响，但从中期来看会造成市场紧张并推高粮食价格。

;

;情况与 2022 年 2 月俄罗斯入侵乌克兰时有很大不同，切断了乌克兰农产品主要出口路线黑海的航运。

;

;基辅是世界上最大的葵花籽油出口国，也是第四大小麦和玉米出口国，并退出了全球市场。市场推动价格在 5 月份创下历史新高。

;

;2022 年 8 月 1 日开放的出口走廊有助于确保进口国的供应并降低价格，即使冲突导致乌克兰农产品产量下降。< /p>;

;泽连斯基表示，乌克兰粮食协议可以在没有俄罗斯的情况下发挥作用

;

;预计 2023-2024 年小麦产量将从 2021-2022 年产量 3300 万吨降至 1750 万吨。

;

;玉米产量预计将从 4200 万吨降至 2500 万吨。

;

;“2023-2024 年，乌克兰应减少出口 600 万吨小麦和 1000 万吨”提供农业市场数据和分析的 Agritel 分析师 Gautier Le Molgat 表示，缺乏直接影响的部分原因是时机：目前是北部地区的收获季节

;

;“未来的需求将在收获结束时变得清晰，”Le Molgat 说道。

;

;“这是市场的平静时期，市场对收成的消息反应不大。交易暂停，”他补充道。

;

;欧洲小麦期货小幅走高，而美国小麦期货下跌。

;

;此外，俄罗斯拒绝续签交易也是意料之中的事情，因此已经在努力破坏它。

;

;在过去的几个月里，“我们发现博斯普鲁斯海峡出现了交通非常缓慢的瓶颈”，特别是由于俄罗斯对使用该走廊的船只进行检查的人数很少” 大宗商品贸易公司 Plantureux & Associes 的交易员爱德华·德·圣丹尼斯 (Edward de Saint-Denis) 表示。

;

;甚至在黑海走廊开放之前，欧盟就已经创建了“团结通道”，即旨在促进团结的陆地和河流路线。欧盟农产品通过欧洲出口。

;

;专门研究农业问题的智库农场基金会估计，乌克兰一半的农产品出口已经走这些路线。

;

;“其中一个农场基金会研究主任奥利亚·塔耶布·谢里夫（Olia Tayeb Cherif）表示：“需要问的问题是，自冲突爆发以来，欧盟已经接收了一半的乌克兰粮食，它是否有能力重新出口这些粮食。” .

;

;欧盟希望通过与乌克兰协调铁路轨距来提高其运输能力。

;

;“他们可以稍微加快速度，但这并不能解决问题圣丹尼斯说。

;

;目前全球市场上并不缺乏小麦。但是，Inter-Courtage 大宗商品经纪公司的 Damien Vercambre 指出，“最适合出口的小麦在俄罗斯，其库存量为 1,250 万吨，而且是世界上最便宜的小麦。”由于缺乏乌克兰小麦而导致世界市场出现短缺。但对俄罗斯的依赖增加对许多国家来说可能是一粒苦药。

;

;预计将有正常收成的欧盟也可以帮助满足进口国的需求。

;

;但不利的天气可能会很快改变前景。

;

;小麦和玉米市场目前的状况也截然不同。作为世界最大的玉米进口国，中国可能会转向巴西，该国的收成创历史新高，且售价较低。

;

;俄罗斯要求滞留的克里米亚游客经被占领的乌克兰开车回家

;< p>;对于小麦来说，产量可能充足，但乌克兰出口量下降可能会产生问题。

;

;“走廊的长期关闭将影响粮食价格通胀，从而影响粮食安全”，农场基金会的 Olia Tayeb Cherif 说道。

;

;一些进口国已经难以支付当前价格，例如埃及。

;

;联合国世界粮食计划署也面临中断的风险谢里夫指出，由于该公司从乌克兰采购小麦，因此将其供应给阿富汗、也门和非洲国家。

;海关人员在香港国际机场检获近2.3公吨违禁药物周二公布的数据显示，今年上半年的货运量和乘客量比 2022 年同期增长了 80% 以上。

;

;最新数据显示，预计毒品数量为 2,298 公斤。据香港海关称，今年 1 月至 6 月期间，机场共查获 604 起案件，价值 9.7 亿港元（1.24 亿美元）。

;

;去年同期，海关查获了 604 起案件。 331宗案件共1,270公斤毒品，价值5.9亿港元。 2022年全年，海关人员在机场共检获839宗毒品，共查获2.6吨毒品，价值12亿港元。

;

;机场检获的违禁毒品占上半年检获毒品的88%

;

;今年1月至6月，海关人员在机场货运站截获516件空运货物，每件携带毒品少于5公斤，而在机场货运站查获此类案件302件。

;

;海关缉毒局局长冯伟清周二表示，去年多次查获藏在机器中的大量毒品后，国际犯罪集团改变了贩毒方式。

;

; p>;

;“最近，他们倾向于在每个包裹中放入较少量的毒品，但将大量包裹（含有非法毒品）邮寄到城市，以增加成功的机会，并减少万一物品被盗时的损失。 ”他说。

;

;香港海关六个月内在机场逮捕了 30 人，查获价值 3,900 万港元的毒品

;

;他将这些包裹描述为“雷明顿霰弹枪发射的多发子弹” ”，同时发出数十批货物，希望其中一些能够到达预定目的地。

;

;“我们相信[贩毒集团]已经考虑到了丢失部分货物的风险，”Fung 说。

;

;在去年涉及机器的最大缉获行动之一中，警方在 3 月份从墨西哥空运的一批货物中发现了 447 公斤液态甲基苯丙胺（称为冰毒），这些液体藏匿在三个变压器中。在随后的突击行动中，他们在上水的一个仓库中又发现了253公斤的毒品。查获的毒品总价值估计达 4 亿港元。

;

;今年机场没收的毒品中，大麻占四分之一。今年前六个月，警方截获了 572 公斤毒品，比去年同期的 98 公斤增加了 480%。其中大部分来自北美。

;

;今年 1 月至 6 月期间，机场查获的可卡因也增加了 208%，达到 241 公斤，而去年同期为 78 公斤。

;

;为了避免被发现，贩毒集团将毒品包装成食品，例如早餐麦片和茶叶，或者将它们藏在玩具和书籍中。

;

;冯说，毒贩招募人员来拾取包裹并在包裹上签名，然后将其藏在玩具和书籍中。他们还改变了收集地点，以避免在控制下交付行动中被便衣海关人员抓获。

;

;香港海关查获价值 3.34 亿港元运往悉尼的冰毒

;

;“此前，他们使用地址来收取包裹。目前，他们找借口从街上的送货员那里取包裹。

;

;他警告公众不要被容易赚钱的诱惑走入贩毒行列。

;<冯说：“人们不应为他人携带不明物品，或向他人提供个人资料或家庭地址以接收包裹或货物。”

;

;机场检获的毒品总量激增还包括去年取消Covid-19旅行限制后，因贩运而被捕的航空乘客数量增加。

;

;香港海关4个月内在机场查获价值8亿港元的毒品

;< p>;今年 1 月至 6 月期间，有 30 名航空旅客因涉嫌走私 45.9 公斤价值 3,900 万港元的非法毒品而被捕，而 2022 年同期则有超过 7 人被拘留。

;

;海关官员表示他们相信，在香港完全向世界重新开放后，国际贩毒集团增加了利用快递员向香港走私毒品的情况。

;

;在香港，贩运危险药物最高可判处终身监禁

;

;海关表示对贩毒活动采取零容忍态度，并会继续监察毒品趋势，并与内地及海外海关合作执法机构解决这个问题。

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 11:50:03 +0800 China jobs: trash inspector with a master’s degree shows how ‘education reform is imminent’https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3228004/china-jobs-trash-inspector-masters-degree-shows-how-education-reform-imminent?utm_source=rss_feed

;这是关于 2023 年上半年经济动荡的系列文章中的第一篇陷阱和逆风让中国努力摆脱多年来新冠病毒引发的锈迹。

;

;25岁的刘毛毛以劳动力人口标准来看已不再被视为年轻。这意味着她的失业并没有反映在 16-24 岁“年轻人”就业市场不断恶化的情况中。

;

;相反，她的失业问题——就像其他二十多岁的苦苦挣扎的成年人一样——现在已经成为了人们关注的焦点。反映在更广泛的失业率中。

;

;“希望我最终能找到一份比学士学位更重要的工作——比如销售——需要更多思考和创新的工作，”她说。 “不然我多花三年的时间读书还有什么意义呢？”

;

;刘女士在河南省一所大学完成研究生学业已有一个月左右了。她心中有理想的工作，但她怀疑可能需要几个月的时间才能找到理想的工作。

;

;“竞争比我想象的还要激烈。 “即使是过去几年没人愿意考虑的职位，现在也有很多人申请。”拥有旅游管理硕士学位、想进入国企工作的刘说。

;

;随着人口减少和老龄化，人才红利能否让中国保持竞争力？

;

;如果公务员制度不成功，她愿意在公立大学任教，因为公立大学往往比私立高等教育资金更充足、更稳定。中国的教育机构。然而，她指出，由于缺乏博士学位，在公立大学工作可能会变得特别困难。

;

;但刘继续为自己喜欢的事情设定远大的目标，即使这意味着放弃工作而不是工作。直到她至少彻底探索了自己的选择为止。

;

;她说，她的一些高等教育同学 - 那些最近在毕业前和毕业后立即找到工作的人 - 已经满足于“安于一个机会”具有类似资格的申请人数量持续增长，而中国经济复苏持续显现出紧张迹象。

;

;这些因素导致许多年轻人将工作保障放在首位，无论是否可以找到任何工作，都可以找到工作它正在实现或利用他们在所选研究领域中积累的知识和专业知识。

;

;鉴于中国城市青年（16-24岁）的失业率不断触及新高，这也许并不令人意外，根据官方数据，其中 6 月份创下了 21.3% 的历史纪录。 5 月份为 20.8%，4 月份为 20.4%，随着毕业临近，人们的担忧加剧。

;

;与此同时，6 月份城镇调查失业率总体保持在 5.2% 不变。

;

;“2023 届毕业生获得的工作机会普遍比之前的班级差，”刘辩称。她还指出，年复一年，许多在大流行期间毕业的人仍在寻找工作，从而产生了复合效应。

;

;随着人口教育水平的提高，中国当局不断试图兜售“就业”的概念。不断上升的“人才红利”——反映了大学毕业生对城市的经济影响——以打消人们对中国劳动力萎缩的担忧。然而，越来越多的毕业生也发现，当他们试图将自己的学位与相关工作相匹配时，他们的才能被浪费了。

;

;人们从事与学位无关、与学位无关的工作的例子最近在中国网民中引起了一些热议。

;

;在最近的一个案例中，广东省广州市的一个街道政府上个月分别招聘了两名拥有学士和硕士学位的人作为垃圾分类检查员——垃圾处理人员。据中央人民广播电台报道，该职位只要求副学士学位，但受过良好教育的申请者都提出了申请。

;

;“没有理由拒绝”拥有更高学历的人，一位工作人员被引述为

;

;随着北京在生育率下降和人口老龄化的背景下推动建立未来增长的“高素质”人才库，这已成为一种趋势。

;

;称之为“ “人才红利”——与过去几十年中国人口红利逐渐减少相比，官员们认为，中国仍然拥有9亿劳动力，整体受教育程度不断提高，为发展提供强大动力。;

;尽管中国人口峰值早于预期，去年减少了85万至14.12亿，但根据官方经常引用的政府数据，去年刚刚进入就业市场的年轻人平均受教育年限为14年

;

;但一些专家警告称，中国实现人才红利仍面临巨大挑战，包括高等教育质量差、学生专业与就业岗位不匹配、教育投资回报率下降等。

;

; p>;

;中国教育科学研究所高级研究员褚朝晖表示，“当人们找不到合适的位置时”，谈论人才红利是没有意义的。

;

;他指出，大学毕业生人数逐年增长（今年达到创纪录的 1158 万人），但这并不意味着中国正在培养许多企业想要的人力资源。

;

;拥有高级学位并不一定足够.

;

;“一个不可否认的事实是，当今中国许多硕士或博士持有者缺乏判断力以及信息和科学素养，”他说。 “我们现在的教育是消耗社会财富却没有回报。”国家金融与发展研究院研究员卢明涛在研究中发现，高等教育投资回报率下降从 1982 年的 60% 以上下降到 2015 年的 10%，Lu 预计到 2030 年将保持在这个水平左右。

;

;Lu 指出，到目前为止，这一比例已下降到与美国类似的水平.

;

;“如果我们留在这里，就不是什么大问题。但考虑到未来中国高等教育的大幅扩张，美国在人才密集型、高附加值的现代服务业的主导地位，以及人工智能对人类工人的快速替代，我们需要警惕进一步的下降。 ”，他解释道。

;

;然而，据统计，随着越来越多的婴儿潮一代（二战后出生的人）退休且出生率仍然很低，美国的人才竞争力也受到劳动力萎缩的影响。乔治城大学麦考特公共政策学院教授哈里·霍尔泽 (Harry Holzer) 说道。

;

;“我们这里存在劳动力短缺，特别是在某些职业和行业。在某些方面，这使得美国和中国的情况更加相似，”他说。

;

;“美国的出生率仍然相当低迷。你不想成为像日本这样的地方之一。你的经济趋于停滞。由于年轻劳动力，你需要休息一下。”霍尔泽说。

;

;但国际劳工组织 2020 年的一份报告估计，27% 的美国工人受教育程度过高，而只有 15% 的工人受教育程度不足。加州大学伯克利分校劳工研究与教育中心低工资工作项目主任恩里克·洛佩兹利拉 (Enrique Lopezlira) 表示，这种差距表明美国存在一定程度的“浪费”人才。

;

;尽管美国大学洛佩兹利拉说，吸引“来自世界各地的许多学生”，加拿大和英国大学的竞争日益激烈，越来越多的美国人毕业后前往国外工作。

;

;除了人才外流，一些美国求职者16-24 岁的人已经表示，该国热门领域和理想地区的雇主很少回复工作申请。

;

;伯克利大学本科生扎克·罗克波特 (Zack Rockport) 本月表示，他已在该国提交了近 30 份兼职工作申请。过去六周以来，我们一直在旧金山湾区进行调查，但没有得到可靠的答复。

;

;“自从大流行以来，似乎每个人都在招聘，但没有人在招聘，”他说。

;

;中国研究员卢表示，“如果所谓‘人才红利’指的是对人才的投资回报，那么中国只能通过出口人力资本密集型产品和服务来实现”。他指出了可能的目的地，例如与中国通过“一带一路”倡议进行合作的国家。“一带一路”倡议是北京的一项贸易倡议，旨在将各经济体连接到一个贸易网络中。

;

;他还敦促政府放松对以下领域的工资控制：从科学到文化，他认为，尽管进行了市场改革，但几十年来，这些都因当局的干预而扭曲。

;

;南开大学经济学院人口学教授袁欣表示，中国有一个尽管该国人口下降，但仍拥有充足的具有高等学历的劳动力。但他指出，中国能否充分利用这些学位和技术仍然至关重要。

;

;“人口红利的一个主要指标是就业，”袁说。 “我们看到硕士和博士学位持有者以送餐为生——这表明教育系统生产的东西与市场需求之间不匹配。

;

;“教育改革迫在眉睫。”

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 11:20:02 +0800 Mystery giant golden cylinder puzzles Australia after washing up on remote beachhttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/australasia/article/3228051/mystery-giant-golden-cylinder-puzzles-australia-after-washing-remote-beach?utm_source=rss_feed

;一个神秘的巨型圆顶状物体被冲上澳大利亚偏远的海滩，让当地人、官员和警察感到困惑。

;

;

;据当局称，这个巨大的、明显是金属的物体出现在西澳大利亚州 Green Head 附近的海滩上。

;

;西澳大利亚州警察部队表示在一份声明中表示已对此事展开联合调查。

;

;“我们希望向社区保证，我们正在积极与各州和联邦机构合作，以确定该物体的起源和性质”，警方表示。

;

;与此同时，澳大利亚航天局在推特上表示，该物体可能来自外国火箭坠落的太空碎片。

;

;“我们目前正在调查与位于西澳大利亚朱里恩湾附近海滩上的这个物体有关，”航天局在推特上写道。 “该物体可能来自外国太空运载火箭，我们正在与全球同行联络，他们可能能够提供更多信息。”航天局还警告说，“社区应避免处理或尝试移动物体”，因为其起源尚不清楚。

;

;警方表示，他们不相信该物体来自商用飞机。

;

;当局最初表示该物体被视为“危险物品” ”，但表示西澳大利亚消防和紧急服务部以及化学中心的分析确定该物体是安全的，不会对公众构成风险。

;“该物品的回收和安全移动西澳大利亚警察部队在 Facebook 帖子中表示，将在正式查明该物品及其来源后进行协调。

;

;当地居民 Garth Griffiths 告诉澳大利亚 ABC 新闻，他的邻居周日告诉他这个谜团。他估计该物体长 3 米（10 英尺），宽 2.4 米（8 英尺）。

;

;“昨天的某个时候，一位当地女士和她的伴侣发现它漂浮在格里菲斯告诉新闻媒体。

;航空专家杰弗里托马斯告诉 BBC，该物体可能是去年某个时候坠入印度洋的火箭的燃料箱。

;欧盟正在游说亚洲国家效仿其在人工智能领域的领先地位，采用新的人工智能技术欧盟和亚洲高级官员表示，针对科技公司的规则包括披露受版权保护和人工智能生成的内容。

;

;欧盟及其成员国已派遣官员就管理人工智能的使用与欧盟进行谈判。他们表示，至少有 10 个亚洲国家，包括印度、日本、韩国、新加坡和菲律宾。

;

;欧盟的目标是使其拟议的《人工智能法案》成为蓬勃发展的技术及其数据保护方式的全球基准。法律帮助制定了全球隐私标准。

;

;中国科学家寻求解决方案时，谷歌人工智能专家警告称，可能会出现“数据中毒”

;

;但是，努力说服亚洲政府需要制定严格的新标准七名知情人士告诉路透社，规则的实施受到了冷淡的对待。

;

;许多国家倾向于采取“观望”态度，或者倾向于更灵活的监管制度。

;< p>;官员们要求不透露姓名，因为讨论的范围之前并未报道过，因此仍处于保密状态。

;

;新加坡是亚洲领先的技术中心之一，更愿意在适应当地法规之前了解技术的发展情况该城市国家的一位官员告诉路透社。新加坡和菲律宾的官员担心过于仓促的监管可能会扼杀人工智能创新。

;

;据路透社上个月报道，东南亚国家正在制定自愿准则。就日本而言，它倾向于采取比欧盟倡导的严格方法更宽松的规则，因为它希望通过该技术来促进经济增长并使其成为先进芯片的领导者。

;

;在亚洲的努力是part of a global push by European nations that include talks with countries such as Canada, Turkey and Israel, Dutch digital minister Alexandra van Huffelen told Reuters in an interview.

;

;“We're trying to figure out on how we can make the regulation from the EU copied, applicable and mirrored … as it is with the GDPR,” van Huffelen said late last month, referring to General Data Protection Regulation, the EU's data privacy regime.

;

;The emergence of AI has been hailed as a breakthrough that will usher in an era of rapid advances in science and technology, revolutionising all aspects of human activity, but also painted as an existential threat.

;

;EU lawmakers in June agreed to a trailblazing set of draft rules, which would make companies such as ChatGPT operator OpenAI disclose AI-generated content, help distinguish so-called deep fake images from real ones and ensure safeguards against illegal content.

;

;The proposed legislation, which also envisages financial fines for rule violations, faces resistance from companies, with 160 executives last month signing a letter warning it could jeopardise Europe's competitiveness, investment and innovation.

;

;Still, officials from the EU, which has signed “digital partnerships” with Japan, South Korea, and Singapore, voice optimism they can find common ground with international partners to advance cooperation on technologies including AI.

;

;“Our mission is again to make sure that what's happening in the EU, which is our large constituency if I may say so, is protected,” EU industry chief Thierry Breton told Reuters during a trip to South Korea and Japan to discuss AI and semiconductors.

;

;“I believe that it will be probably not too far from each other because we share the same values,” Breton said of regulation of AI in the EU and countries such as Japan.

;

;Leaders of the Group of Seven (G7 ) economies made of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Britain, the United States and the European Union, in May called for adoption of standards to create “trustworthy” AI and to set up a ministerial forum dubbed the “Hiroshima AI process ”.

;

;Seoul will continue discussing AI regulation with the EU but is more interested in what the G7 is doing, a South Korean official said following a meeting with Breton.

;

;The EU is planning to use the upcoming G20 meetings to further push for global collaboration on AI, notably with 2023 president India, van Huffelen told Reuters.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 10:20:02 +0800 Japan-Saudi Arabia ties: a green-energy gambit or was ‘everything about China’?https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/economics/article/3228001/japan-saudi-arabia-ties-green-energy-gambit-or-was-everything-about-china?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 09:30;
;;

;Japan and Saudi Arabia have agreed to strengthen decarbonisation and clean energy collaboration after Prime Minister Fumio Kishida met Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Jeddah on Sunday, amid what analysts say are deepening concerns in Tokyo about China's efforts to extend its diplomatic and military reach in the region.

;

;“Everything that has gone on in Saudi Arabia is about China, just as Kishida's recent visit to the Nato summit in Vilnius was designed to rally support on China,” said Jeff Kingston, director of Asian Studies at the Tokyo campus of Temple University.

;

;The two leaders signed 26 memorandums of cooperation on Sunday. These largely involved trade, with many focused on energy as Japan works to secure stable supplies – and Saudi Arabia tries to diversify away from fossil fuels.

;

;Japan imports more than 95 per cent of its oil from the Middle East, with Saudi Arabia accounting for about one-third of that. The importance of stable supplies of oil – and at prices that do not fluctuate wildly – has been underlined by the war in Ukraine.

;

;Tokyo also agreed to step up the delivery of green-energy technology to boost Saudi Arabia's solar-power capabilities as Riyadh looks to move away from an economy that relies almost exclusively on fossil fuels.

;

;“We are shifting from the existing relationship of an oil importer and an exporter and will deepen a new global partnership for the decarbonisation era,” Kishida said.

;

;The two leaders also agreed to set up “strategic dialogue” at the foreign ministerial level to deepen bilateral cooperation.

;

;Kingston pointed out that China has been aggressively expanding its Belt and Road Initiative infrastructure push to grow global trade and has “made inroads into Africa and the Middle East, and Japan is keen to counter that” through diplomatic initiatives.

;

;Will rising global oil prices be the catalyst for Asia's green-energy growth?

;

;China is a major consumer of Middle Eastern oil, making it a key economic partner, but Beijing has also begun to intervene diplomatically in the region as it looks to increase its influence, most recently in agreements to reduce tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran as well as to de-escalate the kingdom's long-running conflict with Yemen.

;

;“For China, the most important connections through belt and road agreements are in Europe and the Middle East, but down the road that will shift to Africa,” Kingston said.

;

;“The continent [of Africa] is seen as China's big, bright future and there have already been many agreements with countries there over natural resources, land and infrastructure.”

;

;Japan believes that Saudi Arabia could be a stepping stone for greater Chinese access to Africa in addition to being a critical source of energy, Kingston said, making closer ties with Riyadh of paramount importance.

;

;Yoichi Shimada, an international-relations professor at Fukui Prefectural University, agreed with that assessment but said he believed Japan's task has been made significantly more difficult by US President Joe Biden's administration.

;

;“In the short term, Kishida wants to make sure that the oil continues to flow to Japan, but he exerts relatively little influence over the Saudi Arabian leadership,” he said. “In truth, Saudi Arabia has turned to China because of Biden's obsession with reducing carbon emissions … That has only served to alienate the Saudis.”

;

;Is Asia finally turning away from filthy fossil fuels to embrace green energy?

;

;Shimada said he believes that Kishida should have emphasised the importance Tokyo places on its relationship with Riyadh to guarantee the ongoing delivery of natural resources, with concerns over carbon emissions being of secondary importance.

;

;“Japan should make it clear that it has no interest in meddling in Saudi Arabia's internal politics because the alternative could be that Riyadh is forced even closer to China, which could imperil the whole world,” he said.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 09:50:02 +0800 ‘One-day marriage’ boom in rural China sees single men pay ‘professional brides’ US$500 to secure ancestral grave burial rightshttps://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/trending-china/article/3227733/one-day-marriage-boom-rural-china-sees-single-men-pay-professional-brides-us500-secure-ancestral?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 09:00;
;;

;It looked just like an ordinary village wedding in northern China as an emcee gave a speech in front of dozens of relatives and friends on July 7.

;

;“Let us celebrate the new couple who are holding their solemn wedding ceremony today, and wish them a lifetime of happiness,” the host said.

;

;But the marriage between the “new couple” would only last for a day.

;

;The magazine Phoenix Weekly reported that “one-day marriages” are trending in rural parts of Hebei province among single men who long to enter their ancestral grave after they die.

;

;In some areas, superstition holds that men who are too poor to attract a wife – often disparagingly called guanggun or “bare branches” – cannot be buried in their family gravesite or enter the ancestral hall.

;

;This could damage the family's feng shui and curse them with generation upon generation of single men.

;

;Many believe men who are allowed to enter the ancestral grave will be looked after by the family's offspring and enjoy paper money and other objects they burn for them in the afterlife.

;

;According to the report, one-day ceremonial marriages became popular in the area five or six years ago. They have become an alternative to the once prevailing ghost marriage, in which one or both parties are dead.

;

;A matchmaker, surnamed Wu, who runs a business arranging one-day marriages, said she had several “professional brides” available.

;

;She charges the men 3,600 yuan (US$500) to rent a bride and 1,000 yuan as her brokerage fee.

;

;The “brides” attend the wedding ceremony and visit the man's ancestral grave with him to let his ancestors know they are “married”.

;

;She said most of the “brides” were nannies or masseuses who were not local, as many worried the business might harm their reputations.

;

;The fake bride in the July 7 wedding, known as Tian, said she needed the money to support her husband and son. She makes a few thousand yuan a month as a massage parlour owner.

;

;Tian said her family did not know about her part-time job as she tried to hide her identity by wearing heavy make-up and wigs during the weddings.

;

;She began working for Wu in 2021 and, at age 48, is the matchmaker's youngest “bride”.

;

;The groom in the July 7 wedding, surnamed Song, called the one-day marriage “a deal” as he did not need to pay for a betrothal gift – usually priced around 100,000 yuan (US$14,000) in the province.

;

;Wu said she was helping the fake grooms and brides, who were “poor people”.

;

;“Nothing is real except for money,” she said.

;

;On mainland social media, the one-day marriage has been compared to an extreme version of a girlfriend or boyfriend rental service, which has become popular among young people seeking to ease marriage pressure from their parents.

;

;Some social online observers were shocked by the men's obsession with entering the ancestral grave.

;

;“First, I don't understand the tradition that single people cannot enter the ancestral grave. Second, why care about entering it so much since you won't be alive then?” one commenter said.

;

;“I have seen those who cheat people many times, but cheating ghosts is something new,” said another.

;

;“They say marriage is the grave of love. It's true,” a third quipped.

;China's grain output for the year is not looking good, as the summer yield is down and more extreme weather looms, analysts warn.

;

;Particularly worrisome is that the autumn harvest, which accounts for 75 per cent of China's whole-year grain production, as they say it is at risk of being lighter due to adverse weather – the primary factor blamed for the first decline in China's summer harvest since 2018.

;

;The country has already faced rarely seen bouts of bad weather this summer, and the subsequently higher risks including drought, flooding and less plant growth, said Huo Xuexi, a professor of agricultural economics from Northwest A&F University.

;

;“I'm afraid that maintaining grain production this year at last year's level would be difficult, given the risks of climatic damage projected by domestic and international meteorologists,” he said.

;

;Rare rains claim millions of tonnes of Chinese wheat right before harvest

;

;Despite increasing efforts to guarantee food self-sufficiency, China has seen a 0.9 per cent drop in summer grain output mainly due to prolonged rain that battered mature wheat in its top-growing province of Henan right before the harvest, the National Bureau of Statistics said at the weekend.

;

;As of last year, China's annual grain output had remained above 650 million tonnes for eight consecutive years amid its strong emphasis on food security in the face of global uncertainties. Beijing aims to at least maintain this level and raise it to 700 million tonnes by 2025, according to the central government's five-year plan for agriculture released last year.

;

;But already this summer, China has recorded the most days with temperatures at 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit) or above since at least 1961, the National Climate Centre said in a WeChat post earlier this month.

;

;The world experienced its hottest week in history from July 3-10, according to the World Meteorological Organization, at the onset of the El Nino climate event that some say will make this the world's hottest year in recorded history.

;

;Seedlings in parts of northern and central China have shown signs of weak growth due to heatwaves since late last month, “bringing grave challenges to autumn harvest”, the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs warned in an article earlier this month.

;

;It said it responded by instructing local governments how to mitigate or reduce the impact on farming.

;

;Zhu Zhen, a researcher from the Institute of Genetics and Developmental Biology under the Chinese Academy of Sciences, said that extreme temperatures, whether too low or too high, would harm crop growth and lead to poor yields.

;

;“We may be able to alleviate droughts and floods, but little can be done to help crops fight extreme temperatures, except for breeding new species more resilient to heat or cold,” he said.

;

;Warning for US, Thai farmers: China to grow 90 per cent of its grain by 2032

;

;And in this regard, “there have been achievements in the laboratory, but to widely apply them still takes time”, he said.

;

;Huo said China needs to make improvements in forecasting the weather and climate patterns, so people can better prepare for inclement weather.

;

;“In Shaanxi, which is a production base for apples, farmers still endure losses due to forecasts that are not timely and precise enough,” he said.

;

;China completed its first national survey on natural disaster risks in February after three years of investigations, assessing the impact of climate change on human health and food production.

;;

;A world-renowned virologist has called on scientists from around the globe to join forces against future pandemics, assembling experts from places such as Hong Kong and mainland China to spearhead research on emerging infectious diseases.

;

;Columbia University's Professor David Ho told the Post that the University of Hong Kong (HKU) and Beijing's Tsinghua University had given their blessing to his plan to build a “Pandemic Research Alliance”.

;

;The scholar, who is acclaimed for discovering the efficacy of a cocktail antiretroviral treatment for Aids, on Saturday said he was in talks with the University of Melbourne about joining the alliance.

;

;“We want to define what are the most important viral threats for pandemics, such as what we went through with coronaviruses, influenza viruses and what we call paramyxoviruses,” he said. “All of these could be easily transmitted from person to person via the respiratory route and therefore could spread very quickly.

;

;“Once we define the most important threats, we could start to study them in greater detail to see if we could develop drugs, antibodies and vaccines, and get them ready. Some of them don't have any of those, and so we could get them ready should one of those emerge as a virus-causing pandemic.”

;

;Ho was one of the first scientists to identify HIV and chart its effects on patients. He was the first doctor to be named Time magazine's Man of the Year, in 1996, after his work on a treatment for Aids helped to improve survival rates.

;

;The virologist collaborated with HKU's Professor Yuen Kwok-yung when the city had an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (Sars) in 2003, and the pair tested antiviral drugs to improve treatment options.

;

;Ho later established a multidisciplinary team of experts at Columbia University during the Covid-19 pandemic with the aim of producing a vaccine.

;

;Hong Kong leader looks at future of healthcare, medical threats in wake of Covid-19

;

;The idea of forming the alliance was inspired by a conversation between scientists from the four institutes about future threats as the recent pandemic began to wane, he said.

;

;“We don't want to go through what we went through over the last 3½ years so we want to be better prepared,” he said. “We expect another pandemic and another pandemic, but no expert could tell you when or where or exactly which part.

;

;“With the environmental changes, the dynamics of human interaction with various animal species are changing and cause perhaps more jumping of viruses from animals to humans and some of them will have pandemic potential.”

;

;The Covid-19 pandemic began in 2020 and has resulted in more than 767 million confirmed cases and over 6.95 million deaths around the world.

;

;The University of Cambridge in 2020 predicted the pandemic would cost the global economy US$82 trillion by 2025.

;

;HKU's Yuen, who plans to join the alliance, on Monday said that although other scientists were also forming teams, the one under Ho had a unique advantage because it was drawing from experts across the Pacific Ocean.

;

;He explained that data from past global pandemics showed that such events were becoming more frequent and largely originated from regions on the ocean's rim.

;

;The different specialities offered by each participating institution would also be crucial in preparing for future outbreaks, Yuen added.

;

;“HKU is best at identifying new viruses as we have found more than 80 new ones in humans and animals. Ho's team specialise in immunology. They have a special understanding of antiviral resistance,” he said. “For Tsinghua University, they did a lot of research and worked on understanding the structure of antibodies. They have also created antibodies for Covid-19 which have been commercialised.

;

;“Researchers in Australia have expertise in pathogenesis. Without knowing any of these areas, it is impossible to prepare for the pandemic.”

;

;The next pandemic? WHO working on list of pathogens to watch

;

;Yuen added that forming an official alliance would make it easier to share research and described such efforts as “complementary”.

;

;“Our exchange of technology, virus strains and specimens will be much closer,” he said. “We will be able to have a division of labour and develop results much faster. In the past, we would not know what others were doing.”

;

;The HKU scholar said the alliance's first step would be identifying viruses originating in animals that could potentially jump to humans. He also expected more experts from regions such as Europe might join in the future.

;

;The world needs China on board to avoid another pandemic disaster

;

;Ho said Hong Kong and the mainland had played a significant role in combating pandemics over the past 20 years and expected that to increase with time.

;

;“Hong Kong faced Sars, then it faced H5N1. I personally witnessed the expansion of expertise here and the greater commitment on the part of scientists and government officials. That improvement is dramatic and admirable,” he said, referring to an outbreak of the bird flu in 1997.

;

;“The same could be said for the institutions in mainland China. It's night and day difference comparing Covid-19 and Sars responses. The expertise is so much greater now and will continue to grow. We, working in the United States, used to come and help. And now the situation is quite different. We've come and collaborated and helped each other.”
